docs.snippet: The president of the American-Arab Relations Committee said yesterday that he would defy President Reagan's ban on travel to Libya in order to meet with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. M. T. Mehdi, who heads the New York-based group, said he would leave ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The president of the American-Arab Relations Committee said yesterday that he would defy President Reagan's ban on travel to Libya in order to meet with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. M. T. Mehdi, who heads the New York-based group, said he would leave Thursday for Libya.

headline.main: U.S. Arab Activist Says He'll Defy Libya Ban

docs.snippet: Hundreds of people still line up every day at employment agencies in Manila, hoping for a chance to get a job in Iraq....
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a presidential order banning Filipino workers from going to Iraq, hundreds of people still line up every day at employment agencies here, hoping for a chance to get a job in that strife-torn country. President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo ordered the ban and withdrew the Philippines' contingent of troops from Iraq in July after insurgents kidnapped a Filipino truck driver and threatened to kill him. Since then, hundreds of Filipinos who had been hired for jobs in Iraq have held demonstrations to demand that the ban be lifted.
docs.abstract: Hundreds of people line up at employment agencies in Manila, Philippines, hoping to get job in Iraq despite presidential order banning Filipino workers from going there; Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo ordered ban and withdrew Philippines' contingent of troops from Iraq after insurgents kidnapped Filipino truck driver and threatened to kill him; since then, hundreds of Filipinos who had been hired for jobs in Iraq have held demonstrations to demand that ban be lifted (M)

headline.main: Filipinos Still Seek Work in Iraq Despite Danger and Ban

docs.snippet: Nearing the end of an 11-day journey through Asia and Oceania, Pope John Paul II sought today to quell a debate among Catholics here over the ordination of women and said women's role in society was specially tied to motherhood.   But while accusi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nearing the end of an 11-day journey through Asia and Oceania, Pope John Paul II sought today to quell a debate among Catholics here over the ordination of women and said women's role in society was specially tied to motherhood. But while accusing his many feminist critics of misunderstanding the Vatican's views, he told a gathering called to honor a nun who fought the male-dominated Australian church hierarchy that "the church stands firmly against every form of discrimination which in any way compromises the equal dignity of women and men."

headline.main: Pope, in Sydney, Defends Vatican's Ban on Ordaining Women

docs.snippet: It seems that nothing short of an earthquake or a fit of sickness can bring me to a sense of my duty as a correspondent. Arrested in mid career of jaunting and junketing, gadding and gossiping, by a severe influenza. I nave a little space for refl...
docs.lead_paragraph: It seems that nothing short of an earthquake or a fit of sickness can bring me to a sense of my duty as a correspondent. Arrested in mid career of jaunting and junketing, gadding and gossiping, by a severe influenza. I nave a little space for reflection and repentance. while looking down from the window of my sick-chamber on the bright, busy world, a part of which I was so little while ago.

docs.snippet: AT American Ballet Theater's gala in May, John Karls was remarkably poised, betraying no sign of pre-performance jitters. But then Mr. Karls is a seasoned performer, a cool veteran of countless opening nights at many of the world's best houses, in...
docs.lead_paragraph: AT American Ballet Theater's gala in May, John Karls was remarkably poised, betraying no sign of pre-performance jitters. But then Mr. Karls is a seasoned performer, a cool veteran of countless opening nights at many of the world's best houses, including what he calls the ''big four'': La Scala, the Vienna Staatsoper, Covent Garden and the Metropolitan Opera House. He knows he will hit his mark. Give or take three feet. Mr. Karls is a tosser. And while he has never personally graced any of those venerable stages, his bouquets have. Hundreds of them. Mr. Karls, 62, started going to operas and ballets and throwing bouquets to his favorite performers at the age of 9, when other boys were throwing to first. He has attended upward of 2,500 performances and tossed some 750 bouquets in a career spanning more than half a century. Such numbers must place the publicity-shy Mr. Karls among the world's elite tossers. (He declined to be interviewed or photographed for this article; some of the descriptions and information here came from letters he has written to the Metropolitan Opera and Covent Garden.)
docs.abstract: Tango Tanner article on John Karls, who attends performances worldwide, and tosses expensive bouquets of roses at divas of ballet or opera as signal of his pleasure with performance; some performers are not enamored of his passion, but others are thrilled; photo (M)
